At that time, Bodhisattva MahÄmati addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Please explain to us the TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddha.
I and the other bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas will then be well-versed in the self-nature of the TathÄgata, and will be able to awaken ourselves and others.
The Buddha told MahÄmati:
Ask as you wish, and I will explain to you according to your questions.
MahÄmati addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Are the TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas created?
Or are they not created?ğŸ”½Are they objects?
Are they causes?ğŸ”½Are they characteristics?
Are they the characterized?ğŸ”½Are they teachings?
Are they the taught?ğŸ”½Are they awakenings?
Are they the awakened?
Are these terms different or not different?
The Buddha told MahÄmati:
The TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, regarding such terms and phrases, is neither an entity nor a cause.
Why is it so?
Because both [possibilities] have faults.
MahÄmati!
If the TathÄgata were an entity, he would either be created or impermanent.
Because of impermanence, all entities would be the TathÄgata.
This is not desired by myself and all Buddhas.
If he were not an agent, because there would be nothing to be attained, the skillful means would be empty, the same as a rabbit's horns or the son of a barren woman, because they do not exist.
MahÄmati!
If there are no entities and no causes, then they are neither existent nor nonexistent.
If they are neither existent nor nonexistent, then they transcend the four propositions.
The four propositions are the worldly expressions.
If they transcend the four propositions, then they do not fall into the four propositions.
Because they do not fall, they are grasped by the wise.
The meaning of all the TathÄgatas' phrases is also like this. The wise should know.
As I have said, all dharmas are without self.
One should understand that this meaning, the nature of non-self, is non-self.
All dharmas have their own nature, not the nature of others, like cows and horses.
Great Wisdom!
It is like the nature of non-cows and non-horses, the nature of horses and cows.
In reality, it is neither existent nor non-existent, they do not lack their own characteristics.
Thus, Great Wisdom!
All dharmas do not lack their own characteristics, they have their own characteristics, but it is not something that foolish ordinary beings can know.
Because of conceptualization, thus all dharmas are empty, unborn, and without self-nature.
One should know it thus.
Thus, the TathÄgata and the aggregates are neither different nor not different.
If they are not different from the aggregates, they should be impermanent.
If they are different, the skillful means would be empty.
If they are two, they should be different.
Like the horns of a cow, they are not different because they are similar;
They are different because of the difference in length.
All dharmas are also like this.
MaheÅ›vara!
Just as the right horn of an ox is different from the left horn, and the left horn is different from the right horn, in this way, long and short, various colors are each different.
MaheÅ›vara!
The TathÄgata is neither different nor not different from the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
In this way, the liberation of the TathÄgata is neither different nor not different.
In this way, the TathÄgata uses the name liberation to speak.
If the TathÄgata were different from liberation, he should be composed of form and characteristics;
because he is composed of form and characteristics, he should be impermanent.
If he were not different, the one who practices would attain non-discrimination in accordance with [the TathÄgata], yet the one who practices sees discrimination.
Therefore, he is neither different nor not different.
In this way, wisdom and its objects are neither different nor not different.
MaheÅ›vara!

Wisdom and the flames are neither different nor not different, neither permanent nor impermanent, neither created nor uncreated, neither conditioned nor unconditioned, neither cognition nor cognized, neither characteristic nor characterized, neither aggregates nor different from the aggregates, neither spoken nor spoken of, neither the same nor different, neither together nor not together.

Because they are neither the same nor different, neither together nor not together, they are all free from all measurements, seeing, hearing, touching, and cognition. Cognition is called a measurement.
Being free from all measurements, there is no speech.
Where there is no speech, there is no arising.
Where there is no arising, there is no ceasing.
Where there is no ceasing, there is quiescent extinction.
Where there is quiescent extinction, there is natural nirvana.
Where there is natural nirvana, there are no events and no causes.
Where there are no events and no causes, there is no mental engagement.
Where there is no mental engagement, one transcends all falsehoods.
Where one transcends all falsehoods, that is the TathÄgata.
The TathÄgata is the One Thus Come, the Perfectly Enlightened One.
MaheÅ›vara,
this is called the TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddha.
Buddha means being free from all faculties and measurements.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Completely free from all faculties and measurements, without affairs and also without causes,
already free from the perceiver and the perceived, also free from characteristics and the characterized.
The aggregates, conditions, and perfect enlightenment, as one or different, cannot be seen.
If there is no seer, how can one discriminate?
Not created and not uncreated, not an affair and also not a cause,
not the aggregates and not in the aggregates, also not mixed with anything else,
also not having various natures, like those seen in deluded thoughts.
One should know that it is also not non-existent, this Dharma is so of itself.
Because of existence, there is non-existence; because of non-existence, there is existence.
If it did not exist, it should not be grasped; if it did exist, one should not conceptualize.
Or dwelling in the measure of verbal expression regarding self and non-self,
Sinking and drowning in the two extremes, destroying oneself and the world.
Liberated from all faults, correctly contemplating my understanding,
This is called right contemplation, not slandering the great guide.
At that time, Bodhisattva MahÄmati again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the World-Honored One has said, the sÅ«tras accept non-arising and non-cessation.
And the World-Honored One has also said that non-arising and non-cessation are an alternate name for the TathÄgata.
World-Honored One, why do you speak of non-arising and non-cessation because of the absence of intrinsic nature?
Or is it an alternate name for the TathÄgata?
The Buddha told MahÄmati:
I say that all dharmas are unborn and unceasing, with existence and non-existence not appearing.
MahÄmati addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If all dharmas are unborn, then the accepted dharmas cannot be obtained, because all dharmas are unborn.
If there is a dharma within names, please explain it to me.
The Buddha told MahÄmati:
Excellent, excellent!
Listen carefully!
Contemplate it well and I shall explain it to you in detail.
MahÄmati said to the Buddha:
Yes, I shall listen to the teaching.
The Buddha told MahÄmati:
I say that the TathÄgata is not without nature, nor is he unborn and unceasing, subsuming all dharmas, nor is he unborn and unceasing because he does not depend on conditions, nor is he meaningless.
MahÄmati!
I say that the TathÄgata's name is the unborn mind-born dharma body. It is not the realm of all non-Buddhists, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas of the seventh stage.
MahÄmati!
That unborn is a different name for the TathÄgata.
MahÄmati!

It is like Indra, Shakra, and Burantadara, and so on, all these things each have many names, but it is not that because there are many names there are many natures, nor is it that there is no self-nature.
Thus, Mahamati!

I have three asaá¹ƒkhyeya hundreds of thousands of names in this Saha world (translated as able to endure), and foolish people all hear them and each call me by my name, but they do not understand that the Tathagata has different names.
Mahamati!
There are sentient beings who know me as the Tathagata, there are those who know me as the Omniscient One, there are those who know me as the
Buddha, there are those who know me as the Savior of the World, there are those who know me as the Self-Realized One, there are those who know me as the Guide,
there are those who know me as the Great Guide, there are those who know me as the Guide of All, there are those who know me as the Immortal,
there are those who know me as Brahma, there are those who know me as Vishnu, there are those who know me as Ishvara, there are those who know me as theğŸ”½Victorious One,
Some know me as Kapila, some know me as the edge of reality, some know me as the moon
, some know me as the sun, some know me as birth, some know me as non-birth, some know me as

some know me as liberation, some know me as the path, some know me as mind-born.
Great Wisdom!
Such are the three asaá¹ƒkhyeya hundreds of thousands of names, neither increasing nor decreasing.
In this and other worlds, all know me as the moon in the water, neither coming out nor entering.
Those foolish people are unable to know me because they fall into the two extremes.

Yet they all respectfully make offerings to me, but they do not understand the meaning of the words and phrases well, do not discriminate the names, do not understand their own abilities, and cling to various verbal expressions and phrases.
Regarding non-arising and non-cessation, they form the notion of having no nature.
They do not know the distinctions in the names of the TathÄgatas, such as Indra, ÅšÄkya, and BhrÄmara.
They do not understand their own abilities and the ultimate return.
They cling to the explanations of all dharmas.
MahÄmati!
Those foolish people say like this:
'The meaning is like the words. The meaning and the words are not different.
Why is it so?
Because the meaning has no body. Apart from the words, there is no other meaning. It is only the words.'
MahÄmati!
Those with evil and burned wisdom do not know the self-nature of words and phrases. They do not know that the arising and ceasing of words and phrases is not the arising and ceasing of the meaning.
MahÄmati!
All verbal expressions fall into written characters, but the meaning does not fall into them.
Because it is apart from existence and non-existence, there is no receiving of birth, and also no body.
Great Wisdom!

The TathÄgata does not speak of the Dharma that falls into written characters, because the existence or non-existence of written characters cannot be obtained, except for not falling into written characters.
Great Wisdom!
If there are those who say that the TathÄgata speaks of the Dharma that falls into written characters, this is false speech.
Because the Dharma is apart from written characters.
Therefore, Great Wisdom!
We Buddhas and Bodhisattvas do not speak a single word or answer a single word.
Why is it so?
Because the Dharma is apart from written characters.
It is not that the meaning is not beneficial, but is spoken.
Speech is due to the deluded thoughts of sentient beings.
Great Wisdom!
If all dharmas are not spoken of, then the teaching will be destroyed.
If the teaching is destroyed, then there will be no Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, or ÅšrÄvakas.
If there are none, then who speaks for whom?
Therefore, Mahamati!
Bodhisattva-mahasattvas should not be attached to verbal expressions, but should extensively expound the Dharma according to the circumstances.

Because the hopes and afflictions of sentient beings are not uniform, I and all Buddhas speak various Dharmas for sentient beings with different understandings, in order to make them transcend mind, thought, and consciousness, not for the sake of attaining the stage of self-realized holy wisdom.
Mahamati!
In all dharmas, one should realize the self-mind's perception and transcend the two kinds of false imagination.
Bodhisattva-mahasattvas should rely on the meaning, not on the words.
If good men and good women rely on words, they will destroy the ultimate truth themselves and will not be able to awaken others.

They will fall into a succession of evil views and expound them to the assembly. They will not be able to understand all dharmas, all stages, and all characteristics, nor will they know the chapters and sentences.

If one understands all dharmas, all stages, and all characteristics, and thoroughly penetrates the phrases and fully possesses the meaning of the nature, then one will be able to enjoy oneself with the bliss of the correct signlessness, and establish sentient beings in the Great Vehicle of equality.
Great Wisdom!
Those who uphold the Great Vehicle uphold the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Sravakas.
Those who uphold the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Sravakas uphold all sentient beings.
Those who uphold all sentient beings uphold the true Dharma.
Those who uphold the true Dharma ensure that the Buddha lineage is not cut off.
Those who ensure that the Buddha lineage is not cut off will be able to understand and attain the supreme entrance.
Knowing and attaining the supreme entrance, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas will always be born through transformation and establish the Great Vehicle.
With the ten powers of mastery, they manifest various forms and appearances.
They thoroughly understand the characteristics of sentient beings' forms, aspirations, and afflictions, and expound the Dharma as it is.
As it is, means not different.
As it is, means the characteristic of neither coming nor going, and the cessation of all false thoughts.
This is called as it is.
Great Wisdom!
Good men and good women should not grasp at and become attached to the teachings.
Because the real is apart from words.
Great Wisdom!
It is like a fool who uses a finger to point at an object. The fool looks at the finger and does not understand the true meaning.

In this way, fools follow the finger of words and grasp at and become attached to them, never letting go until the end, and are never able to attain the foremost true meaning apart from the finger of words.
Great Wisdom!
It is like an infant who should eat cooked food, not raw food.
If they eat raw food, it will make them go crazy.
Because they do not know the sequence of skillful means in cooking.
Great Wisdom!
In this way, if one does not skillfully cultivate non-arising and non-cessation, it will be unskillful.
Therefore, one should skillfully cultivate expedient means, not following verbal explanations like looking at the tip of a finger.
Therefore, Mahamati!
In the true meaning, one should cultivate expedient means.
The true meaning is subtle and tranquil, the cause of nirvana.
Words are the combination of conceptual thoughts.
Conceptual thoughts accumulate birth and death.
Mahamati!
The true meaning is obtained from the learned.
Mahamati!
The learned means being skilled in meaning, not skilled in words.
Those skilled in meaning do not follow any non-Buddhist scriptures or treatises, do not follow them themselves, and do not let others follow them either. This is called a virtuous and learned person.
Therefore, those who wish to seek the meaning should be close to the learned, namely those skilled in meaning. They should be close to the learned, namely those skilled in meaning.
Those who are contrary to this, attached to words, should be far away from them.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄmati, again receiving the Buddha's majestic spiritual power, said to the Buddha:

The World-Honored One has revealed non-arising and non-cessation, but there is nothing extraordinary about it.

These are merely different names for causes and conditions, and the causes and conditions of external things are also like this.
Thus, World-Honored One!
There is no difference between this and the theories of non-Buddhists.
The nine things such as atoms, the supreme, the wondrous, the sovereign, and the lord of beings do not arise or cease.
The World-Honored One has also said that all natures are non-arising and non-cessation, and existence and non-existence cannot be obtained.
Non-Buddhists also say that the four great elements are indestructible, with their own natures, unborn and unceasing.
The four great elements are permanent.
These four great elements, even as they flow through the destinies, do not abandon their own natures.
The World-Honored One's teachings are also like this.
Therefore, I say there is nothing extraordinary.
I only pray that the World-Honored One will explain the differences and why they are extraordinary and surpass the non-Buddhists.
If there are no differences, then all non-Buddhists would also be Buddhas.
Because of non-arising and non-cessation, the World-Honored One has said that it is impossible for many Buddhas to appear in one world.
As explained above, there should be many Buddhas in one world, because there are no differences.
The Buddha told MahÄmati:
I say non-arising and non-cessation is not the same as the non-Buddhists' non-arising and non-cessation.
Why is it so?
Those non-Buddhists have the nature of self-existence, attaining the characteristics of non-arising and immutability.
I do not fall into the category of existence and non-existence like this.
Great Wisdom!
The self is apart from the category of existence and non-existence, apart from arising and ceasing, neither a nature nor without nature.
Because it appears like various illusions and dreams, it is not without nature.
How is it without nature?
It means that form does not have its own inherent nature, because it is grasped and appears, and because it is not grasped and does not appear.

For this reason, all natures are neither with nor without nature. It is only by realizing the perception of one's own mind that deluded thoughts do not arise, and one attains peace, bliss, and the cessation of worldly affairs.
Foolish ordinary beings create things through deluded thoughts, but not the sages.
Unreal deluded thoughts are like gandharva cities and illusory people.
Great Wisdom!
In a gandharva city and illusory person, various beings come and go in their commerce.
Foolish people imagine it to be true coming and going, but in reality there is no coming or going, it is only because of their deluded thoughts.
In this way, Great Wisdom!
Foolish ordinary beings give rise to non-arising and non-cessation, but they also do not have conditioned or unconditioned [dharmas].
Like a phantom person, in reality there is neither arising nor cessation, because nature and non-nature do not exist.
All dharmas are also like this, apart from arising and cessation.
Foolish ordinary beings fall into non-actuality and give rise to the false imagination of arising and cessation, but not the sages.
Those who do not accord with actuality are not so.
The imagination of self-nature and nature are also not different.
If the imagination is different, then one will become attached to the self-nature of all existences and not see tranquility.
Those who do not see tranquility will never be free from false imagination.
Therefore, Mahamati!
The view of signlessness is superior.
The view of signs, because it is the cause for receiving birth, is not superior.
Mahamati!
For the one without signs, false imagination does not arise, and I say that which does not arise and does not cease is nirvana.
Mahamati!
Nirvana is seeing according to true reality, free from the prior conceptual mind and mental factors, and attaining the self-realized holy wisdom of the TathÄgatas. I call this nirvana.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Eliminating the theories of arising, establishing the meaning of non-arising,
I teach such a Dharma, which fools are unable to understand.
All dharmas are unborn, without nature and non-existent,
Like a gandharva, an illusion, and a dream. Those with a nature are without cause.
Without arising and without self-nature, why speak of emptiness as a cause?
Because of being apart from combination, the nature of awareness does not appear.
Therefore, emptiness does not arise. I say it is without self-nature.
Referring to each combination, the nature appears but does not exist.
Analyzing, there is no combination, not like the views of non-Buddhists.
Dreams, illusions, hanging hair, mirages, gandharvas,
Various things in the world appear without cause.
Subduing the theory of causation, expounding the meaning of non-arising,
For those who expound non-arising, the flow of Dharma is eternally unbroken,
Vigorously expounding the theory of causelessness, terrifying the non-Buddhist paths.
How, and on what cause, do they arise?
Where do they come together to make the theory of causelessness?
Observing conditioned phenomena, neither without cause nor with cause,
The views of those who speak of arising and ceasing are thereby extinguished.
What is non-arising? Is it the absence of nature?
Do you consider various conditions, is there a dharma called non-arising?
The name should not be meaningless, please explain it in detail,
It is neither the absence of nature nor non-arising, nor is it considering various conditions,
It is not a real nature that is called, nor is the name also without meaning.
All the non-Buddhists, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas,
The realm of the seventh stage, this is called the characteristic of non-arising.
Far removed from all causes and conditions, also apart from all things,
Only the subtle mind remains, free from both thought and the thought object,
Its body follows the transformation, I say this is non-arising.
Without external nature, without nature, also without the mind grasping,
Cutting off all views, I say this is non-arising.
Thus, without self-nature, emptiness and so forth should be distinguished,
Not empty, therefore it is said to be empty, without arising, therefore it is said to be empty.
When the various causes and conditions come together, then there is arising and ceasing,ğŸ”½Apart from the various causes and conditions, there is no separate arising and ceasing.
Apart from the various causes and conditions, there is no other nature,
If one says they are the same or different, this is the imagination of non-Buddhists.
Existence and non-existence have no nature and do not arise, they are neither existent nor non-existent.
Except for the transformation of numbers, all of this cannot be obtained.
There are only various conventional numbers, which are mutually hooked and chained.
Apart from the chain of causes and conditions, the meaning of arising cannot be obtained.
Arising has no nature and does not occur, free from the faults of non-Buddhists.
It is only said that conditions are hooked and chained, which the foolish and ignorant cannot understand.
If apart from the chain of conditions, there is a nature of arising,
then this is the theory of causelessness, destroying the meaning of the chain.
Just as a lamp illuminates various forms, the chain appears in the same way.
Then, apart from the chain, there are other natures.
Without nature there is no arising, like the nature of space itself.
If apart from the chain, wisdom has nothing to discriminate.
There are also other forms of non-arising, the Dharma attained by the sages.
The arising of that arising is the arising of the four characteristics, which is then the acceptance of non-arising.
Those who contemplate the hook-chains, all free from the hook-chains,
From this attain samÄdhi.
This is the inner hook-chain, the drill-stick, clay-ball, and wheel,
Seeds and so forth are called external.
Arising from causes and conditions, they are not the meaning of the hook-chain,
This is then not established.
If arising has no intrinsic nature, for whom are they the hook-chain?
Because they arise from each other, one should understand the meaning of causes and conditions.
Arising from causes and conditions, they are not the meaning of the hook-chain,
This is then not established.
The foolish give rise to false thoughts, apart from the aggregates there is no different Dharma,
This is then said to be natureless.
There are no various treatises, because of the differences in illness,
Various treatments are prescribed.
Destroying all afflictions, knowing the superiority of their faculties,
For them, he speaks the gateway to liberation.
There are various teachings, but only the teaching of the One Vehicle,
This is then the Great Vehicle.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Great Wisdom again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
All non-Buddhists give rise to the false conception of impermanence.
The World-Honored One also says that all conditioned phenomena are impermanent, being subject to arising and ceasing.
What is the meaning of this?
Is it wrong or right?
How many kinds of impermanence are there?
The Buddha told Great Wisdom:
All non-Buddhists have seven kinds of impermanence, which are not my teachings.
What are the seven?

Some say that after creation, it is abandoned, and this is called impermanence.ğŸ”½Some say that the destruction of form and appearance is called impermanence.ğŸ”½Some say that form itself is impermanent.
Some say that the transformation of form in the middle is called impermanence.
It is destroyed by itself without interval, like milk turning into curd and so on, which cannot be seen in the middle. Impermanence destroys all natures and causes them to transform.
Some say that nature is impermanent.
Some say that nature and non-nature are impermanent.
Some say that all dharmas are unborn and impermanent, and enter all dharmas.
Mahamati!
As for nature and non-nature being impermanent, it means the self-characteristics of the four elements and their derivatives are destroyed.
The self-nature of the four elements cannot be obtained and is unborn.
As for that unborn being impermanent, it is neither permanent nor impermanent.

The existence and non-existence of all dharmas are unborn. Analyzing down to the smallest particle, it cannot be seen. This is the meaning of non-arising, not arising. This is called the characteristic of non-arising impermanence.
If one does not realize this, one falls into the meaning of the arising of impermanence of all non-Buddhists.
Mahamati!
As for nature being impermanent, it is the self-mind's conceptualization, not the nature of permanence or impermanence.
Why is it so?
It is because the self-nature of impermanence is indestructible.
MaheÅ›vara!
This is the impermanence of the nature of all existences.
Except for impermanence, there is no one who can make the nature of all dharmas non-existent.
Like a stick or a stone, it destroys all things.
It is seen that each is not different. This is the impermanence of nature, not that the creator and the created have different characteristics.
This is impermanence, and this is the created.
If the creator and the created are not different, then all natures are permanent and without a cause.
MaheÅ›vara!
The impermanence of the nature of all existences has a cause, which is not known by ordinary foolish people. It is not that dissimilar things arise without a cause.
If they arise, then all natures would be impermanent.
This is a dissimilar thing.
The creator and the created do not have any difference.
But they are all seen to have differences.
If the nature is impermanent, it falls into the characteristics of the cause of creation.
If it falls, then all natures are not ultimate.
If all natures fall into the characteristics of the cause of creation, then the impermanent should be impermanent.
Because of impermanence being impermanent, all natures are not impermanent, and should be permanent.
If impermanence enters all natures, it should fall into the three times.
Past form is together with destruction, future form is not born, because form is not born, present form is together with the characteristic of destruction.
Form is the distinction of the aggregation of the four great elements.
The nature of the four great elements and derivative form is indestructible, because it is neither different nor not different.
All non-Buddhists think that the four great elements are indestructible, and the four great elements and derivative form in the three realms of existence are subject to birth and cessation.
Apart from the four great elements and derivative form, what do all non-Buddhists think of as impermanent?
The four great elements are unborn, because their inherent characteristics are indestructible.
Apart from impermanence that is created from the beginning, it is not the four great elements.
Moreover, there are different four great elements, each with different characteristics.
Because of their inherent characteristics, they cannot be distinguished, and they are without distinction.
These are not created again, and the two skillful means are not done. One should know that this is impermanence.
As for the impermanence of the destruction of form and place, it means that the four great elements and the form they create are indestructible, and ultimately indestructible.
Great Wisdom!
As for the ultimate, it means analyzing down to the smallest particle and observing destruction.
The four great elements and the form they create have different appearances of length and shortness, but they cannot be obtained. They are not the four great elements.
The four great elements are indestructible, but the form and place are destroyed and appear.
One falls into the SÄá¹ƒkhya philosophy.
As for the impermanence of form itself, it means that form is itself impermanent.
Then the form and place are impermanent, but not the four great elements.
If the four great elements are impermanent, it is not the worldly conventional expression.
If the worldly conventional expression is not a nature, then one falls into worldly philosophy.
Seeing that all natures are only words, one does not see the arising of their own characteristics.
As for impermanence through transformation,
